transcript:
Patient: One thought that's been coming up a lot is, "I'm not good enough." I catch myself thinking this whenever I make a mistake at work or feel like I'm not meeting my own expectations.

Therapist: That's a common thought that many people struggle with, and it can be a difficult one to challenge. Let's explore this thought further using the downward arrow technique. This will help us uncover the underlying beliefs that contribute to this thought.

To start, can you think of a specific situation where you had the thought, "I'm not good enough"?

Patient: Yes, just last week I made a mistake on a project at work. It wasn't a huge mistake, but I still felt like I had let my team down.

Therapist: Okay, let's use that situation as our starting point. So, when you made that mistake, you thought, "I'm not good enough." If that thought were true, what would it mean to you?

Patient: It would mean that I'm not capable of doing my job well.

Therapist: And if you're not capable of doing your job well, what would that mean?

Patient: It would mean that I'm not valuable to my team or my company.

Therapist: And if you're not valuable to your team or your company, what would that mean?

Patient: It would mean that I'm not successful or worthwhile as a person.

Therapist: Okay, so we've identified a core belief that seems to be underlying the thought "I'm not good enough" - the belief that your worth as a person is tied to your success or value at work. This is a common belief, but it's one that can contribute to a lot of distress and self-criticism.

Let's look at this belief more closely. What evidence do you have that your worth as a person is tied to your success or value at work?

Patient: Well, I've always based a lot of my self-esteem on my achievements at work. And I see other people who are successful in their careers being respected and admired.

Therapist: And what evidence do you have against this belief?

Patient: I know that there's more to me than just my work. I have other qualities and relationships that are important to me. And I've known people who are successful in their careers but aren't necessarily happy or fulfilled in other areas of their lives.

Therapist: You've identified some important pieces of evidence against the belief that your worth is tied to your success at work. It's true that there are many aspects of ourselves and our lives that contribute to our sense of self-worth and fulfillment.

Now, let's see if we can come up with an alternative belief that takes into account the evidence you've identified. What's a more balanced way of looking at your worth as a person?

Patient: I guess a more balanced belief would be, "My worth as a person comes from many different aspects of myself and my life, not just my success at work. I can still be a valuable and worthwhile person even if I make mistakes sometimes."

Therapist: That's a great alternative belief. It acknowledges that your worth is multifaceted and not solely dependent on your work performance. How does it feel to consider this alternative perspective?

Patient: It feels more compassionate and realistic. Like I'm not putting so much pressure on myself to be perfect at work all the time.

Therapist: That's a great observation. By challenging the belief that your worth is tied to your success at work and adopting a more balanced perspective, you can start to reduce some of that pressure and self-criticism.

As we continue to work on challenging negative thoughts and beliefs, it's important to remember that this is a process. It takes time and practice to shift long-held beliefs, but with consistent effort, it becomes easier to offer ourselves compassion and see ourselves in a more balanced way.

Let's continue to practice this process of examining the evidence for and against our beliefs and generating alternative perspectives. As we do this, we'll start to uncover more of the underlying beliefs that contribute to negative self-talk and develop more adaptive and balanced ways of thinking about ourselves.

Can you think of another situation where you noticed yourself having negative thoughts about yourself?
